source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.72
description: Author names MUST use full first names, not initials. Chicago emphasizes complete names for clarity. The first author's name is inverted (Last, First Middle), while subsequent authors use normal order (First Last).

examples.error_reason: Uses initials instead of full first name (APA habit)
Uses initials for both first and middle names

common_errors: Using initials instead of full names (APA habit)

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.72
description: First author name MUST be inverted (Last, First Middle). This applies to all source types and facilitates alphabetical ordering in the bibliography.
common_errors: Not inverting the first author's name
Inverting all author names instead of just the first

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.76
description: For TWO authors: use 'and' between names (second name NOT inverted). NEVER use ampersand (&). The word 'and' is required for Chicago's formal style.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.76
description: For THREE authors: list all names. First author inverted, remaining in normal order, separated by commas with 'and' before the last.

examples.citation: Smith, John, Jane Doe, and Bob Wilson

examples.error_reason: Uses 'et al.' for only 3 authors (MLA habit)

examples.citation: Smith, John, Doe, Jane, and Wilson, Bob

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.76
description: For 4-10 authors: list ALL names in bibliography. First author inverted, all subsequent authors in normal order. Unlike MLA, do not use 'et al.' until 11+ authors.

examples.citation: Smith, John, Jane Doe, Bob Wilson, and Mary Johnson

examples.error_reason: Uses 'et al.' for 4 authors (must list all through 10)

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.76
description: For 11+ authors: list first 7 authors + 'et al.' This prevents excessively long entries while maintaining attribution.

examples.citation: Smith, John, Jane Doe, Bob Wilson, Mary Johnson, Tom Brown, Lisa White, Mike Green, et al.

examples.error_reason: Lists only first author (should list first 7)

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.79
description: Corporate/organizational author: Use organization name as author. Do not abbreviate unless commonly known by acronym.

examples.citation: U.S. Department of State. Foreign Relations...

common_errors: Omitting 'The' when part of official name

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.79
description: NO AUTHOR: Begin entry with title. Do not use 'Anonymous' or placeholders. Alphabetize by first significant word (ignore A, An, The).

examples.citation: The Chicago Manual of Style. 17th ed. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2017.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.104
description: Editor notation: Use 'Edited by First Last' (spelled out, NOT abbreviated 'ed.' or 'eds.'). For edited books without author, editor comes first with ', ed.' or ', eds.' suffix.

examples.citation: Tylor, Edward B. Researches into the Early Development of Mankind. Edited by Paul Bohannan. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1964.
Rafoth, Ben, ed. A Tutor's Guide. New Hampshire: Heinemann, 2000.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.85
description: ALL titles MUST use Title Case (Headline Style). Capitalize first and last words, and all major words (nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs). Lowercase articles (a, an, the), prepositions, and coordinating conjunctions unless first/last word.

examples.error_reason: Uses sentence case instead of Title Case

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.85
description: Subtitle capitalization: Capitalize first word after colon in subtitles, regardless of word type.

examples.citation: Beloved: A Novel of Love and Memory

examples.error_reason: First word after colon not capitalized

common_errors: Not capitalizing first word after colon

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.86
description: Complete works use ITALICS: Book titles, journal names, film titles, websites. These are standalone, self-contained works.

examples.error_reason: Uses quotation marks for book title

common_errors: Using quotation marks instead of italics

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.86
description: Shorter works use QUOTATION MARKS: Article titles, chapter titles, poems, short stories, songs. These are works contained within larger works.

examples.error_reason: Missing quotation marks for article title

common_errors: Using italics instead of quotation marks

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.86
description: Do NOT use both italics AND quotation marks on same title. Choose one based on whether work is complete (italics) or contained (quotes).

examples.error_reason: Uses both italics and quotation marks

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.129
description: CRITICAL: Place of publication is REQUIRED for books. This is a major difference from APA and MLA. Format: Place: Publisher, Year.

examples.error_reason: Missing place of publication (REQUIRED in Chicago)

common_errors: Using comma instead of colon after place

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.129
description: Colon separates place from publisher: Place: Publisher. No colon after publisher - use comma before year.

examples.error_reason: Uses comma instead of colon after place

common_errors: Using comma instead of colon after place

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.184
description: Journal volume and issue format: Volume, no. Issue (Year): pages. Note the parentheses around year and colon before pages.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.184
description: NO 'p.' or 'pp.' before page numbers in Chicago. Simply include the page range directly after the colon.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.129
description: Publisher names: Write out in full (don't abbreviate). Omit initial articles like 'The' but keep other parts.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.72
description: Periods separate major elements in bibliography entries. Unlike footnotes (which use commas), bibliographies use periods after author, title, and at end.

examples.citation: Kerouac, Jack. The Dharma Bums. New York: Viking Press, 1958.
Kerouac, Jack, The Dharma Bums, New York: Viking Press, 1958
examples.error_reason: Uses commas between major elements (footnote style)

common_errors: Using commas instead of periods (footnote habit)

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.72
description: Every bibliography entry MUST end with a period. This applies regardless of whether the entry ends with a URL, DOI, date, or other element.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.72
description: Period after author name, followed by title. The author's name is a complete element ending with period.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.184
description: Colon before page numbers in journal citations. After the year in parentheses, use a colon followed by the page range.

examples.error_reason: Uses comma instead of colon before pages

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.8
description: DOI preferred over URL when both available. DOIs are permanent identifiers and should be formatted as full URLs: https://doi.org/10.xxxx/xxxxx

examples.error_reason: Uses 'doi:' prefix instead of URL format

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.8
description: Access dates: Include ONLY when no publication date available. Format: 'Accessed Month Day, Year.' Note the American date format (differs from MLA).
common_errors: Including access date when publication date exists

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.8
description: Do NOT use 'Retrieved from' before URLs. Simply include the URL directly, without introductory phrase.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.8
description: Database name may substitute for URL. When citing through academic databases, the database name can replace the URL.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.67
description: 3-em dash rule: When listing multiple works by same author, traditional Chicago allows replacing author name with 3-em dash (———) in subsequent entries. However, 17th edition DISCOURAGES this practice.

examples.citation:
Morrison, Toni. Beloved. New York: Knopf, 1987.
———. Song of Solomon. New York: Knopf, 1977.

Morrison, Toni. Beloved. New York: Knopf, 1987.
Morrison, Toni. Song of Solomon. New York: Knopf, 1977.

validation_note: Accept BOTH formats - 3-em dash OR repeated author name. This is a stylistic choice.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.67
description: Multiple works by same author: Arrange chronologically (oldest to newest). If same year, alphabetize by title.

examples.citation:
Morrison, Toni. Song of Solomon. 1977.
Morrison, Toni. Beloved. 1987.

common_errors: Alphabetizing by title instead of chronologically

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.100
description: Basic book format: Author Last, First. Book Title. Place: Publisher, Year.

examples.citation: Kerouac, Jack. The Dharma Bums. New York: Viking Press, 1958.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.103
description: Edited book format: Author Last, First. Book Title. Edited by First Last. Place: Publisher, Year.

examples.citation: Tylor, Edward B. Researches into the Early Development of Mankind. Edited by Paul Bohannan. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1964.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.106
description: Translated book format: Author Last, First. Book Title. Translated by First Last. Place: Publisher, Year.

examples.citation: Cortazar, Julio. Hopscotch. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. New York: Pantheon Books, 1966.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.107
description: Chapter in edited book: Author Last, First. "Chapter Title." In Book Title, edited by First Last, page range. Place: Publisher, Year.

examples.citation: Harris, Muriel. "Talk to Me: Engaging Reluctant Writers." In A Tutor's Guide, edited by Ben Rafoth, 24-34. New Hampshire: Heinemann, 2000.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.175
description: Basic journal format: Author Last, First. "Article Title." Journal Name Volume, no. Issue (Year): page range.

examples.citation: MacDonald, Susan Peck. "The Erasure of Language." College Composition and Communication 58, no. 4 (2007): 585-625.

common_errors: Using sentence case for article title

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.175
description: Online journal with DOI: Add DOI at end as full URL.

examples.citation: Rennie, Kriston. "The Normative Character of Monastic Exemption." Medieval Worlds 6 (2017): 61-77. https://doi.org/10.1553/medievalworlds_no6_2017s61.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.207
description: Website with author: Author Last, First. "Page Title." Website Name. Publication/modification date. URL.

examples.citation: Ross, Andrea. "'It Still Fits': Diamond Ring Missing Since 2004 Turns Up on Garden Carrot." CBC.ca. Last modified August 15, 2017. http://www.cbc.ca/...

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.207
description: Website without author (corporate): Organization. "Page Title." Date or Accessed Date. URL.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.203
description: Newspaper article: Author Last, First. "Headline." Newspaper Name, Month Day, Year.

examples.citation: Deo, Nisha. "Visiting Professor Lectures on Photographer." Exponent (West Lafayette, IN), Feb. 13, 2009.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.265
description: Film (DVD/Physical): Director Last, First, dir. Title. Original Year; Place: Distributor, Release Year. Format.

examples.citation: Singer, Bryan, dir. The Usual Suspects. 1995; Santa Monica, CA: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, 2014. DVD.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.267
description: YouTube video: Author/Username. "Video Title." YouTube video, duration. Date. URL.

examples.citation: Bellaimey, John. "The Five Major World Religions." YouTube video, 11:09. November 14, 2013. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m6dCxo7t_aE.

notes: YouTube videos often cited only in notes, not bibliography

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.291
description: Federal document: Country. Department/Agency. Title. Place: Publisher, Year. URL (if online).

examples.citation: U.S. Department of State. Foreign Relations of the United States: Diplomatic Papers, 1943. Washington, DC: GPO, 1965.

source: Chicago Manual of Style 17th Edition, Section 14.215
description: Dissertation/Thesis: Author Last, First. "Title." PhD diss. or MA thesis, Institution, Year.

examples.citation: Rutz, Cynthia Lillian. "King Lear and Its Folktale Analogues." PhD diss., University of Chicago, 2013.
